item.title: robots enlisted in round 4 of search for flight 447 wreckage
item.description: deep-sea robots are crisscrossing the atlantic to find out what caused air france flight 447 to disappear nearly two years ago.

item.description: jason heyward is being held out of the atlanta braves' starting lineup for the second straight game because of his sore right shoulder.

item.title: u.s. expands seeding of biomass

item.title: britain releases guidance on new anti-bribery law
item.description: the law would exempt companies whose shares are listed in britain but which do not have operations there.

item.title: ninety wounded in northern iraq protests
item.description: at least 90 people were wounded in a second straight day of clashes between protesters and security forces in the northern iraqi city of sulaimaniya on monday, police and medical sources said.

item.title: tweety was right: cats are a bird's no. 1 enemy
item.description: while public attention has focused on wind turbines as a menace to birds, a new study shows that a far greater threat may be posed by a more familiar antagonist: the house cat.

item.title: at war: kirkuk tensions highlight concerns over u.s. troop exit
item.description: the highly unusual step of putting american forces in the field on their own highlights how serious the situation is in kirkuk ahead of the planned exit of the american military by the end of the year.

item.title: accused california serial killer investigated in new york
item.description: a california photographer charged with killing four women whose first and last names began with the same letter is also being investigated in the unsolved murders of three girls in rochester, new york, police said on wednesday.

item.title: apple supplier hon hai seeks hi-tech future
item.description: hon hai precision industry, apple inc's biggest manufacturing partner, is seeking to transform itself into a technology firm and leave behind the low-margin contract business that has made it one of the world's biggest makers of other firms' products with revenues expected to top $101 billion this year.

item.title: fda approves bristol-myers melanoma drug
item.description: the first drug to help patients with advanced melanoma live longer won u.s. approval on friday, a major step in the fight against one of the deadliest types of cancer.

item.title: new orleans mayor, police chief take aim at murder rate
item.description: the new orleans mayor and police chief vowed on friday to better address violent crime in a city where the murder rate is more than 10 times the national average.

item.title: players want to be in training camps by late july
item.description: nfl players are hoping to be back on the training fields by the end of next month, a players association official said wednesday.

item.title: it's the year of the pitcher, part ii
item.description: the baseball season is only 40-some days old and already 2010's year of the pitcher is having quite an encore: two no-hitters and several near misses.

item.title: australia's qantas offers redundancies to cabin crew
item.description: australia's qantas airways said it expects to cut around 350 of its cabin crew jobs, or 5 percent of total, under a voluntary redundancy program as the airline seeks to reduce costs to offset higher fuel prices.

item.title: new york deputy sheriff killed, wife goes into labor
item.description: a deputy sheriff in upstate new york was fatally shot while trying to calm a man attempting suicide, and his death prompted his wife to go into labor on tuesday with their second child, authorities said.

item.title: nhl's flyers trade for rights to phoenix goalie ilya bryzgalov
item.description: the philadelphia flyers traded for the rights to phoenix netminder ilya bryzgalov on tuesday and will look to strike a deal with the russian after the coyotes failed to retain him.

item.title: gbagbo detained by french in his residence, aide says
item.description: french special forces have detained ivory coast's laurent gbagbo and handed him to leaders of the rebel opposition, after french tanks forced their way into his residence, a gbagbo adviser in france said.

item.description: emergency crews on rescued eight miners who had spent six hours trapped in a caved-in coal mine in southeastern colombia.

item.title: reality tv, shaking off recession, takes entrepreneurial turn
item.description: if reality television could be considered an economic indicator, perhaps the recovery is under way. two networks are betting on shows based on entrepreneurs competing for seed money.

item.description: a rules official said rule 18-2b was being modified to eliminate a player's stance as one of two banned factors for causing a ball to move.

item.title: hemophilia drug often used in other patients: study

item.title: at a time of needed financial overhaul, a leadership vacuum
item.description: the financial regulatory system was remade under dodd-frank and requires strong leaders, but five major bank regulatory positions are either unfilled or staffed with acting directors.

item.title: wal-mart sets new $15 billion buyback of lagging stock
item.description: wal-mart stores inc announced a $15 billion share repurchase and emphasized a recent dividend rise to hearten shareholders who have seen the stock lag as its u.s. sales remain in a prolonged slump.

item.description: iron chef morimoto joins other top chefs in quest to help japan.

item.description: with oil refineries out of commission and clogged roads slowing gasoline deliveries, japan turned to electric cars to help provide needed services.

item.description: the senate on monday voted 72 to 16 to confirm a white house lawyer, donald verrilli jr., as solicitor general.

item.title: connecticut avoids layoffs by reaching union accord

item.title: yankee stadium concession workers sue over tips
item.description: three current and former waiters who served fans in premium seats at yankee stadium have filed a lawsuit against their employer over the withholding of tips automatically charged on food and drink orders.

item.title: cocaine once part of film budgets, dennis quaid says
item.description: actor dennis quaid says his biggest mistake was getting addicted to cocaine, but that the drug was so prevalent in hollywood in the 1980s that supplies were built into the budgets of movies.

item.title: business group says doha round hopes fading
item.description: chances for a deal this year in long-running world trade talks are fading and likely will remain remote unless world leaders become personally involved, an influential u.s. business group said on monday.

item.title: kuwait to mediate in bahrain crisis
item.description: bahrain's largest shi'ite opposition group wefaq has accepted kuwait as a mediator with bahrain's government to end a political crisis gripping the tiny kingdom, a member of wefaq said on sunday.

item.description: a late easter drove more spending on clothes this april than last, but gas prices and the weak housing market continued to crimp americans' spending ...

item.description: the united nations human rights body voted thursday for the appointment of an investigator to monitor and report on iran in response to its crackdown on political dissent.

item.description: hundreds of customers queued outside apple stores in asia and europe to buy an ipad 2 tablet computer amid fears that shortages in the united states would be repeated abroad.

item.description: a fire tore through an altoona duplex tuesday morning, killing five people, officials said.

item.title: survivors of priest abuse make proposal to church
item.description: the archdiocese of san francisco has settled 101 abuse cases and paid $68 million in settlements to survivors since 2003, but bay area victims want the church to go further.

item.description: california has joined a whistleblower lawsuit that claims bristol-myers squibb bribed doctors to prescribe its drugs.

item.title: the tv watch: terror hearing puts lawmakers in harsh light
